skills.general: Software engineer proficient in front-end development, fascinated by blockchain and smart contracts.

experience.description: As a software engineer within the Atala team, I developed and led  all of our web-based projects. Some of the responsibilities that I have are; designing and implementing features in collaboration with the team, breaking down work and helping prioritizing, and reviewing code from other engineers.
accomplishments: Developed and led web-based projects in the Atala team.
Collaborated in designing and implementing features.
Developed SSI web dApp platform and internal component UI library using modern technology.
Maintained Atalaâ€™s main website and SSI docs website.
Developed multiple prototypes and supported the wallet SDK team.

experience.description: As a digital developer, I successfully managed diverse web and native projects, both small and large, including legacy updates, delivering tailored solutions for brands like Sainsbury's and HSBC. Alongside this, I supported my team by troubleshooting, sharing knowledge, and adapting to new technologies efficiently.
accomplishments: Managed web and native projects for brands like Sainsbury's and HSBC.
Developed responsive web projects and mobile applications.
Updated legacy projects and crafted reusable React UI Components.
Automated content integration using Google APIs.

experience.description: As a freelancer, I've navigated the rewarding challenge of working solely with individuals. This journey involved actively seeking projects, connecting with new clients, and transforming their unique ideas into custom websites, all while enjoying the fulfillment and financial rewards of my craft.
accomplishments: Worked with individuals on bespoke web solutions.

education.focus: Udemy, an online learning site, has been great for learning new web development skills. I learned how to build modern websites, develop big Node applications for the web, create RESTful APIs, and understand authorization. I got better by watching expert tutorials and practicing a lot.

Pluralsight, an online learning site, really helped me improve. It made my design skills better and helped me understand JavaScript more deeply. I learned a lot about advanced JavaScript topics like closures, prototype inheritance, maps, scope, the event loop, and the 'this' context. I got better by watching experts and practicing regularly.

Codecademy, an online interactive site, was where I started learning web development. I learned the basics of HTML, CSS, JavaScript, and jQuery there. I got better by doing different coding exercises, reading, and practicing regularly.
